row.name: BRCA Cancer Risk Infographic Crops[#5922]
row.field_accessible_version: Infographic showing the genetic risk of developing breast cancer by age 70. Women with a mutated BRCA1 gene have a six-in-ten chance of breast cancer by age 70. Women with a mutated BRCA2 gene have a four-in-ten chance of breast cancer. Women with a normal BRCA gene have a one-in-ten chance of breast cancer by age 70.
row.field_caption: Determining breast cancer risk: The discovery of BRCA1 and BRCA2 gene mutations improved screening and treatment decisions for breast and ovarian cancers.

row.name: RAS Pathway V2[#2818]
row.field_accessible_version: The diagram shows 227 genes arranged in 65 groups containing one to 29 genes per group.
row.field_caption: The diagram shows 227 genes arranged in 65 groups containing one to 29 genes per group.  The proteins represented by gene names in a group are thought to carry out similar, but probably not identical, functions. Gene names separated by periods represent proteins believed to form physical complexes. At the top of the diagram are the receptors and messengers to the three RAS proteins. The RAS proteins in turn signal through six alternative effector families to affect many downstream targets including TP53, RB1, and MTOR.  Arrows represent activation signals, dotted  "T" lines represent inhibitory signals. The bracket connecting KSR1 and KSR2 to the RAF, MAP2K, and MAPK genes represents a scaffolding function.

row.name: lymph system, male, anatomy[#4391]
row.field_accessible_version: Anatomy of the lymph system, showing the lymph vessels and lymph organs including lymph nodes, tonsils, thymus, spleen, and bone marrow. Lymph (clear fluid) and lymphocytes travel through the lymph vessels and into the lymph nodes where the lymphocytes destroy harmful substances. The lymph enters the blood through a large vein near the heart.

row.name: multiple myeloma[#5879]

row.field_caption: Multiple myeloma. Multiple myeloma cells are abnormal plasma cells (a type of white blood cell) that build up in the bone marrow and form tumors in many bones of the body.

row.name: thyroid and parathyroid gland anatomy[#5878]
row.field_accessible_version: The thyroid gland lies at the base of the throat near the trachea. It is shaped like a butterfly, with the right lobe and left lobe connected by a thin piece of tissue called the isthmus. The parathyroid glands are four pea-sized organs found in the neck near the thyroid. The thyroid and parathyroid glands make hormones.
row.field_caption: Anatomy of the thyroid and parathyroid glands. The thyroid gland lies at the base of the throat near the trachea. The parathyroid glands are four pea-sized organs found in the neck near the thyroid.

row.name: urinary system, male and female, anatomy[#9746]
row.field_accessible_version: Anatomy of the male urinary system (left panel) and female urinary system (right panel) showing the kidneys, ureters, bladder, and urethra. Urine is made in the renal tubules and collects in the renal pelvis of each kidney. The urine flows from the kidneys through the ureters to the bladder. The urine is stored in the bladder until it leaves the body through the urethra.
row.field_caption: Anatomy of the male urinary system (left panel) and female urinary system (right panel).

row.name: bone anatomy (spanish)[#5561]

En un corte trasversal del hueso, se muestran el hueso compacto y los vasos sanguíneos en la médula ósea. También se muestran los glóbulos rojos, los glóbulos blancos, las plaquetas y las células madre sanguíneas.
row.field_caption: Anatomía del hueso. El hueso se compone de hueso compacto, hueso esponjoso y médula ósea.

row.name: urinary system, male and female, anatomy (spanish)[#9746]
row.field_accessible_version: Anatomía del sistema urinario masculino (panel izquierdo) y el sistema urinario femenino (panel derecho) que muestra los riñones, uréteres, vejiga y uretra. La orina se elabora en los túbulos renales y se acumula en la pelvis renal de cada riñón. La orina fluye desde los riñones a través de los uréteres a la vejiga. La orina se acumula en la vejiga
row.field_caption: Anatomía del sistema urinario masculino (panel izquierdo) y el sistema urinario femenino (panel derecho).

row.name: multiple myeloma (spanish)[#5879]
row.field_accessible_version: Mieloma múltiple; en la ilustración, se muestran células plasmáticas normales, células de mieloma múltiple (células plasmáticas anormales) y anticuerpos. También se muestra la médula roja en el hueso, en donde se elaboran las células plasmáticas.
row.field_caption: Mieloma múltiple. Las células de mieloma múltiple son células plasmáticas anormales (un tipo de glóbulo blanco) que se acumula en la médula ósea y forma tumores en muchos huesos del cuerpo.

row.name: liver anatomy (spanish)[#6836]
row.field_accessible_version: Anatomía del hígado; la figura muestra los lóbulos derecho e izquierdo del hígado, los conductos biliares, la vesícula biliar, el estómago, el bazo, el páncreas, el colon y el intestino delgado. Los lóbulos posteriores del hígado no se muestran.
row.field_caption: Anatomía del hígado.  El hígado tiene cuatro lóbulos.  Dos lóbulos están adelante del hígado y dos lóbulos pequeños (que no se muestran) están atrás del hígado.

row.name: paraganglioma anatomy (spanish)[#1170]
row.field_accessible_version: Paraganglioma de la cabeza y el cuello; la imagen muestra el tumor cerca de la arteria carótida en la cabeza y el cuello.
row.field_caption: Paraganglioma de la cabeza y el cuello. Tumor poco común que con frecuencia se forma cerca de la arteria carótida.  También se puede formar sobre las vías nerviosas en la cabeza y el cuello y en otras partes del cuerpo.

row.name: gallbladder anatomy (spanish)[#1554]

row.field_caption: Anatomía de la vesícula biliar. La vesícula biliar está justo debajo del hígado.

row.name: respiratory system anatomy (spanish)[#2573]
row.field_accessible_version: Anatomía respiratoria; el dibujo muestra el pulmón derecho con los lóbulos superiores, medios e inferiores; el pulmón izquierdo con los lóbulos superiores e inferiores; y la tráquea, los bronquios, los ganglios linfáticos y el diafragma. El recuadro muestra los bronquiolos, los alvéolos, la arteria y la vena.

row.name: lymph system, male, anatomy (spanish)[#4391]
row.field_accessible_version: Anatomía del sistema linfático; se muestran los vasos linfáticos y los órganos linfáticos, incluidos los ganglios linfáticos, las amígdalas, el timo, el bazo y la médula ósea. La linfa (un líquido claro) y los linfocitos se desplazan a través de los vasos linfáticos hasta los ganglios linfáticos, donde los linfocitos destruyen las sustancias que son dañinas. La linfa entra en la sangre a través de una vena grande cerca del corazón.

row.name: GD2 CAR CD19 CAR[#3819]
row.field_accessible_version: Fluorescent imaging of T cells with GD2 CAR receptors on the surface
row.field_caption: Fluorescent imaging of T cells with CAR receptors on the surface. The GD2 CAR (left) spontaneously aggregates, resulting in antigen-independent signaling, T cell exhaustion, and poor efficacy. The highly effective CD19 CAR (right) does not aggregate and does not signal in the absence of antigen.

row.name: Stage I non-small cell lung cancer[#8353]
row.field_accessible_version: Two-panel drawing of stage I non-small cell lung cancer. First panel shows stage IA with cancer (3 cm or less) in the right lung; also shown are the right main bronchus, trachea, lymph nodes, bronchioles, and diaphragm. Second panel shows stage IB with cancer (more than 3 cm but not more than 5 cm) in the left lung and in the left main bronchus; the carina is also shown. Inset shows cancer that has spread from the lung into the innermost layer of the lung lining; a rib is also shown.
row.field_caption: A panel of genetic markers may identify patients with stage I lung cancer with a poor prognosis, suggesting that they may benefit from post-surgical chemotherapy.

row.name: Brain Anatomy Adult[#1149]
row.field_accessible_version: Drawing of the inside of the brain showing the supratentorium (the upper part of the brain) and the infratentorium (the lower back part of the brain). The supratentorium includes the cerebrum, ventricles (fluid-filled spaces), choroid plexus, hypothalamus, pineal gland, pituitary gland, and optic nerve. The infratentorium includes the cerebellum and brain stem (pons and medulla). The spinal cord is also shown.
row.field_caption: Craniopharyngiomas can damage parts of the brain, including the hypothalamus, pituitary gland, optic nerve, and brain stem, causing serious neurological problems.

row.name: Understanding Precision Medicine[#8076]
row.field_accessible_version: Illustration of precision medicine, three bottles of medication pointing to groups of people
row.field_caption: Using the genetic changes in a patient’s tumor to determine their treatment is known as precision medicine.

row.name: Newborn baby feet and letters of A, T, C G[#3255]
row.field_caption: A new study has provided the most accurate assessment to date on the possible role of inherited mutations in childhood cancers.

row.name: Glioblastoma cells[#3336]
row.field_accessible_version: Glioblastoma cells
row.field_caption: Glioblastoma cells in culture. Researchers hope that immunotherapies will improve outcomes in patients with this aggressive brain cancer.

row.name: Woman Receiving Bad News from Doctor[#8609]
row.field_caption: Tell your doctor if you are extremely tired or have other signs of anemia. There are treatments that may help.

row.name: Woman Making a Smoothie[#7201]
row.field_caption: People being treated for cancer often don’t feel hungry. Sometimes, preparing food in new ways – such as making a smoothie – can make it easier to eat.

row.name: Two Hispanic Women Walking on a Trail[#7990]
row.field_caption: Managing fatigue is an important part of your cancer treatment plan. Taking short walks and getting light exercise can actually increase most people’s energy level.

row.name: African-American Woman Wearing Scarf in Clinic[#4292]
row.field_caption: If treatment will cause hair loss, try wearing fun scarves and earrings – or a cap, from time to time.

row.name: Man Washing Hands[#4027]
row.field_caption: Good hand washing practices can help to prevent infection, which is especially important when a person is being treated for cancer.

row.name: Dispensing Pills[#5772]
row.field_caption: Cancer treatments can cause nausea and vomiting. These side effects can be prevented by medicine. Sometimes, several different medicines may need to be tried to find the one that works best.

row.name: Elderly Woman Smiling with a Nurse[#9444]
row.field_caption: People with nerve problems caused by cancer treatment need to take care to prevent falls. Sometimes integrative medicine practices, advised by your doctor, can also help you to feel better.

row.name: A male doctor showing male patient results[#5971]
row.field_caption: Treatment for cancer may cause changes to a boy’s or a man’s fertility.

row.name: Moisturizing Hands with Lotion[#9023]
row.field_caption: When cancer treatments cause skin and nail problems, there are creams and lotions that can help your skin to feel better.

row.name: African-American Man Sleeping[#7350]
row.field_caption: People going through treatment for cancer may have changes in their sleep patterns or difficulty sleeping. Tell your nurse about any difficulties you are having, so you can get the help you need to sleep better at night.

row.field_caption: Corte transversal de un liposoma. Al encapsular irinotecan en un liposoma ayuda a que el fármaco permanezca por más tiempo en circulación, por lo que es más probable que llegue a las células cancerosas y las destruya.
